children.subject: Yeah AI and ML is the most competitive field to get into. Try doing systems research behind the AI? I had friends with 3.4s get into those positions. Also try doing more side projects and all.

I disagree about it being the most competitive, in the sense that I feel like 70% of the applicants applying had their work mainly in coding/aren't as strong as math, which is why it seems so "competitive". In general I think the math heavy-subfields in ML/AI are fairly alright to get into, if you know what you're doing.

Yeah unfortunately the <3.3 GPA is probably what's hurting you. In my experience professors care more about GPA than, for example, companies do (and even then companies care quite a bit). It raises questions of whether you'd be intellectually capable and hard-working enough. It doesn't help that professors in AI get lots of requests from undergrads, e.g. you're competing against people with 3.8+ GPAs. Try doing really well in a professor's class (A+) or talking to professors that don't work directly in AI?
Some do and some don't. Abiel and Wagner do use GPA. Though they are very popular professors.
Who are you doing research with? Are there any professors doing AI research that don't really look at GPA?

Well if I say who, I won't be anon anymore :) but one is for CS theory another is for ML/AI/Stats.

Note: I am not a very smart individual nor consider myself a top student.

***

Yes there are. You just have to keep trying and have the guts never to give up

If I can direct message you I'd be glad to talk more
John Canny I think is not as stingy on GPA. My friend works for him.
I disagree, both professors in which I do research with never asked for anything to do with my GPA. Just go to their OH and talk to them. Professors are nice people
3.5 + is really good. But once again if you are applying to places like Peter's lab that's probably the hardest lab to get into. For systems type research 3.5 should be more than fine.
Would you mind elaborating more on what kind of researches are systems type? Also, what do you think is the best and most efficient way to get involved in research? Thanks so much for your help.

I also find it so hard to get a research position. I really feel frustrated as I tried many ways such as applying through URAP and emailing professors. I have an ok gpa (3.5+), but I feel it is so competitive to get involved in research in EECS department. Really appreciate any suggestion. Thanks!

3.5-3.7 isn't a bad GPA at all! Is AI research really that competitive? It is kind of frustrating how professors use GPA as pretty much the sole determiner of research capability, but I guess they have no other metric to go on. Does industry experience count for anything?
If I wanted to go to Berkeley for grad school (probably in AI) would a 3.5 GPA be enough?

I think it is hard to get into Berkeley grad school no matter what... Particularly for AI. If gradschool is your goal, I would cast a wide net. However, GPA isnt the only thing they consider for gradschool. Great recommendation letters and research are more important. Keep in mind to get in, you will essentially need a professor to say that they want you as their grad student. The best way for this to happen is if you work with someone who wants you to continue working with them, which brings you back to finding research now :/

(this is all assuming you are interested in a PhD and not a masters)

I had a mediocre GPA compared to what many AI profs expect. (ranging from 3.5-3.7 depending on the semester)

I 100% understand the frustration and rejection. I had to look a little bit outside the standard to find research, but was able to find some decent fits by looking outside the direct departement.

I would consider places like: Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (http://www.lbl.gov/),  International Computer Science Institute (https://www.icsi.berkeley.edu/icsi/) or maybe even the iSchool. LBL & ICSI definitely have cool things going on, and they are not the first places that many ugrads look. I think LBL has some supper specific programs, though you may be able to find things during the year. ICSI does not have direct programs, but sometimes a researcher will send out calls for ugrads

history.content: Hi! I'm an undergrad looking for research positions in EECS (specifically AI related). I've applied to URAP and emailed professors and postdocs but I usually get no response. Every other year I've applied to URAP I've also never gotten a response :( I think this might probably be because I have a less than stellar GPA (<3.3 technical), but I'm not really sure.  What are some of the factors professors take into consideration when looking for student researchers? And what's the best way to reach out to them to ensure a response?
history.subject: Research positions for EECS?
